titlestmt.titleproper: Foundation Center of New York records
A Guide to the Foundation Center of New York records FA023
titlestmt.author: Beth Jaffe-Davis

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-06-09 00:03:57 -0400.

did.unittitle: Foundation Center of New York records

physdesc.extent: 173 microfilm reels, 1 half-letter document box, 40 bound volumes

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Foundation Center was created in 1956 by foundation leaders who felt the need for an independent organization that would collect and make available information about philanthropic and non-profit organizations in the United States and throughout the world. On May 25, 1956, the Foundation Library Center was incorporated as an educational institution under the authority of the New York State Board of Regents. The Center was to gather comprehensive information about foundations, stimulate reporting and accountability where it did not yet exist, and provide "a convenient place where any person may find accurate information about foundations."

F. Emerson Andrews, long-time president of the Russell Sage Foundation, was the first president of the Foundation Center, serving from 1956-1966. He wrote extensively on the topic of philanthropic and non-profit organizations and was a strong advocate for a central information-collecting agency. He was succeeded by Manning M. Pattillo (1967-1970), Thomas R. Buckman (1971-1991), and Sara Engelhardt (1992-2008).

The books, reports, and files of the Russell Sage Foundation formed a core collection of the Foundation Library Center. The Center also purchased photographic transcripts of financial and other data on approximately 7,000 organizations, and it solicited complete annual reports files where they existed. The library opened to the public in late 1956. In 1960, the Center published its first Foundation Directory.

In 1968, the Foundation Library Center changed its name to the Foundation Center. For further information see its website, http://foundationcenter.org, and its publication "Philanthropy in the 21st Century: The Foundation Center's 50th Anniversary Interviews."

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The records are divided into five series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of the Foundation Center span the years 1922-2004, with the majority of the records dating from the mid-1950s, when the Center was created, to the early 1990s. Most of the material prior to 1956 comes from F. Emerson Andrews, the first president of the Foundation Center. Prior to 1956, Andrews had worked at the Russell Sage Foundation, and much of the correspondence relating to the Foundation Center was addressed to him there.

Containing correspondence, annual reports, financial records, publications, clippings, and a large collection of organizational pamphlets, the collection reveals the history of the Foundation Center and its projects, including fund-raising programs, the directories, "Foundation News," and various seminars in technology and other areas of interest. It also provides a history of governmental influence and tax reform in relation to non-profit organizations. The collection contains manuscripts and articles by F. Emerson Andrews on the world of philanthropic organizations, including his book "The Foundation Watcher." It also includes photographs, a Foundation Center video entitled "Foundations: The People and The Money," a scrapbook containing articles on the Congressional tax reform hearings, and transcripts from these hearings.
The Foundation Center collection exists on 173 reels of 35mm preservation standard microfilm.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Microfilm user copies are available for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Published material that is readily available elsewhere (such as books or transcripts of Congressional hearings)and special format material, including audio and visual materials and computer disks and punch cards, have been separated and retained in their original formats. "Separation sheets" placed within the microfilmed collection will note the existence of this original documentation.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The following books were removed from the Foundation Center collection and placed in the Rockefeller Archive Center library. They are available for research use.
Andrews, F. Emerson. Foundation watcher. Lancaster, PA: Franklin and Marshall College, 1973. Copy 2: Inscribed by author; autographed. Call Number: 361.7 AND.
America's voluntary spirit: a book of readings. Ed. Brian O'Connell. New York: Foundation Center, 1983. Call Number: 361.7 ROC.
An agile servant: community leadership by community foundations. Ed. Richard Magat. New York: Council on Foundations, 1989. Call Number: 361.8 AGI.
Zurcher, Arnold J., and Dustin, Jane. The foundation administrator: a study of those who manage America's foundations. New York: Russell Sage Foundation, 1972. Call Number: 361.7068 ZUR.
Duane, Thomas David. Opthalmic research: U. S. A.: a comprehensive national survey of eye research. New York: Research to Prevent Blindness, 1965. Call Number: 612.8 DUA.
Layton, Daphne Niobe. Philanthropy and voluntarism: an annotated bibliography. New York: Foundation Center, 1987. Call Number: 361.7016 LAY.
Kiger, Joseph C. Historiographic review of foundation literature: motivations and perceptions. New York: Foundation Center, 1987. Call Number: 361.7016 KIG.
The literature of the nonprofit sector: a bibliography with abstracts. New York: Foundation Center, 1989-1994. Call Number: 361.7016 LIT.
The foundation directory. Ed. David G. Jacobs. New York : Foundation Center, 2003. Call Number: 2nd Floor/361.7025 FOU.
Foundation Center. Annual report. New York, 1956-2007. (Variant Title, 1956-1967: Foundation Library Center annual report.) Call Number: 2nd Floor, Annual Reports.
Foundation Center. Foundation Center: 50th anniversary: knowledge to build on. New York, 2006. Call Number: 361.706 FOU.
Philanthropy in the 21st century. Ed. Mitch Nauffts. New York : Foundation Center, 2007. Call Number: 361.706 PHI.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.p: This series is arranged in two subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains historical information about The Foundation Center, including staff charts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries A is arranged in 9 parts:
2 - F. Emerson Andrews and Manning M. Pattillo, Jr.
4 - Manning M. Pattillo, Jr. and Thomas R. Buckman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: F. Emerson Andrews served as the first president of The Foundation Center, 1956-1966. Before his time at The Foundation Center, he was president of the Russell Sage Foundation. He was very interested in and studied philanthropic foundations. His papers consist of correspondence, manuscripts and other published works, and material relating to the Jellicoe Foundation. The Jellicoe Foundation was a fictitious foundation created by Andrews to see if other publishing houses were copying from The Foundation Directory. If Jellicoe Foundation was in the other directory he knew they copied directly and without The Foundation Center's permission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 1.2A.9 is labeled "Deceased Trustees." At the time of filming many of these Trustees were not yet deceased. The material was originally labeled in this way because many of the trustees had passed away; but several of the trustees mentioned (such as Vernon Jordan) were placed in the category of "deceased" after declining to accept a Trustee Emeritus position with the Center.
This series contains correspondence and newspaper clippings about The Foundation Center's trustees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, minutes, and agenda of various large committees in The Foundation Center: the Board of Trustees, the Executive Committee, and the Finance and Audit Committee.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series 2 is arranged in two subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information in Series 2.1 is primarily centered around financial material and fund-raising that The Foundation Center actively pursued.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Associates Program is a fee-based program. Being a member of the Associates Program gave an organization the opportunity to use the resources of The Foundation Center for a small fee on top of the yearly fee. A primary benefit of membership was the ability to draw on the vast database The Foundation Center maintained.

These centers provide a core collection of The Foundation Center's publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains files relating to a grants reporting system that enabled grant-seekers and grant-makers to identify grants in specific fields of interest. The system was based on a classification system using a national standard for classifying non-profit organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains files of correspondence, newspaper clippings, a scrapbook, and IRS forms having to do with the changes in the tax system for non-profit organizations.

scopecontent.p: Series 3.2A includes information about the first of the tax reforms that Congress enacted which affected non-profit organizations.
